notes: Fourth generation Outlander built on Nissan-Renault-Mitsubishi Alliance CMF-C/D platform. Standard 2.5L naturally aspirated engine paired with CVT. S-AWC (Super All-Wheel Control) available on AWD models. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Outlander article, January 17, 2025 revision.

engines: 2.4L I4 + dual electric motors (248 hp combined)
notes: Plug-in hybrid with 20 kWh lithium-ion battery, electric range approximately 38 miles. Twin-motor AWD system with rear-mounted electric motor. High-voltage system requires specialized diagnostic equipment and EV-certified technicians. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Outlander PHEV article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Compact crossover known as RVR in some markets. Third generation continued from 2011 with minor updates. Discontinued after 2024 model year. CVT transmission standard across all trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi RVR article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Refreshed Eclipse Cross with revised styling and turbocharged 1.5L engine. S-AWC system available on AWD models. Turbocharger servicing requires additional attention to oil quality and cooling system maintenance. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Eclipse Cross article, January 17, 2025 revision.
Subcompact hatchback with 1.2L three-cylinder engine. Discontinued in North America after 2023 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Mirage article, January 17, 2025 revision.

Sedan variant of Mirage hatchback sharing same 1.2L three-cylinder powertrain. Discontinued in North America after 2023 model year. Data sourced from Wikipedia Mitsubishi Mirage article, January 17, 2025 revision.
